title: 104_hr4148
content: The "Jackie Robinson Commemorative Coin Act" authorizes the minting of $1 silver coins to commemorate the 50th anniversary of Jackie Robinson breaking the color barrier in baseball. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary will obtain silver for minting coins from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design of the coins will be determined under this Act. Design requirements for the coins minted under this Act include featuring Jackie Robinson on the obverse side and his contributions to baseball on the reverse side. Each coin will also include inscriptions of the coin's value, the year "1997", and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be selected by the Secretary after consultation. The design for the coins featuring Jackie Robinson will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Jackie Robinson Foundation and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility starting April 15, 1997, with minting authority ending on December 15, 1998. The Secretary will sell coins at a price including face value, surcharge, and production costs. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. A $10 surcharge per coin will be included in all sales. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services needed for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales will be paid to the Jackie Robinson Foundation to enhance education programs and provide scholarships for youth in need. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure minting coins won't cost the government. Payment for coins requires full payment, security, or a guarantee from a depository institution. Payment of Surcharges: No surcharge proceeds for coins can go to the Foundation until all costs are recovered and private funds equal or exceed the surcharge amount. Annual audits of recipients are required. Annual audits are required for recipients of surcharge proceeds from coin sales under this Act. The audits must be conducted annually by an independent public accountant selected by the Foundation, in accordance with government auditing standards. The audits will continue until all surcharge amounts received by the Foundation are fully expended or placed in trust. The minimum requirements for the audits include reporting the amount of payments received by the Foundation. The Foundation must report the payments received from surcharges on coin sales, the amount expended from these surcharges, and ensure that all expenditures were for authorized purposes. The Foundation must ensure that payments received from surcharges on coin sales are accounted for separately and expenditures are reported publicly after an audit. The Foundation may use surcharge proceeds to pay for audits and the Secretary can waive certain requirements based on surcharge amounts. The Foundation must provide books and records to the Inspector General to receive surcharge payments. The Foundation must provide books, records, and workpapers to the Inspector General or Comptroller General upon request. No surcharge proceeds can be used to compensate agents or attorneys to influence legislative action. The Foundation cannot use surcharge proceeds to influence legislative action related to the coins minted under this Act.
